Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments withadded plaster) of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black; above,chain of palmettes and buds with rosettes in added white outline and added red centres; below, two white bands above frieze of buds alternating with concentric circles with white band below; exterior: painted decoration consisting of seated sphinx (part of neck, wing, body, rump, one foreleg and paw of hind leg preserved; red patches on wing, body and hindquarters), to left; elaborate spiked rosettes as filling ornaments.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888, 0601.474.a. Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a heavy chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice-kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1). The interior decoration on the sherd stands out as being very elaborate for this style.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 90, p. 121, p. 123, fig. 65, p. 255, no. 440, pl. 59)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1559) (phase 2)
